Since its inception, Half-Life created a cult-like following with its players and fans: for good reason.  When the game first came out, I was hooked.  The story line, the fairly seamless large world, and the controls all make for an excellent combination.

Half Life is an awesome game with a few challenging missions and interesting puzzles. I recommend that if you are planning on playing Half Life 2 you start here as there is absolutly no reason to skip it and since it indirectly provides alot of background information on the storyline. For a game from 1998 it has aged extremely well and will last you a while (it took me 11 hours). It also has a few cool dlcs that are worth playing through if you enjoy the game.

This game. This great, great game. It is simply a timeless classic. For it's time, the graphics were great. The gameplay still, today, feels fun and exciting, running through black mesa, trying to survive against all odds. This game revolutionized gaming and set a new goal for first-person games to beat. The voice acting was, and still, simply is astonishing. Being made by such a small company at the time, it still astounds me to this day. The storyline is great, and each and every weapon feels real and powerful, so each kill feels great/rewarding. I simply love this game and can say nothing more of it other than: "Buy this game!!!"

This game moved the first person shooter Iam the realm of the puzzler. It is quite outdated nowadays when it comes to graphics and gameplay, but it was the beginning of a new era. Long live the Free Man!

Half life 1, well were to begin, everybody and their long lost relatives know what half life is and they also know how much it raised the "FPS" genre onto its feet and pushed the bar high. A lot of modern day shooters fail to provide the atmosphere and the fluid simple controls of this great title, There have been so many people reviewing this game so I'm finding it quite hard to start so i guess i shall start by telling you what the game is about.

-----SPOILERS----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dr. Gordon Freeman arrives late for work at 8:47 am in the Black Mesa Research Facility, using the advanced Black Mesa tram system that leads through the facility. He arrives at the Anomalous Materials Lab, his work place, and he is informed by the security officer that the scientists have a special experiment today, so he goes to the locker room and puts on the hazard suit. He goes to the lab's lower levels, and arrives at the Anti-Mass Chamber, where he is instructed that the specimen to be used that day is the rarest and also the most unstable specimen the lab has ever worked with. He is tasked with pushing the specimen into the scanning beam of the Anti-Mass Spectrometer for analysis. However as soon as he pushes it, it explodes, and creates a sudden catastrophe called a "resonance cascade" 
-----SPOILERS----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The story is really good, its actually quite funny, modern games often spend massive amounts of money on spectacular scenes and explosions and deep heart felt commentary in order to set the mood......But How does half life do it that right with a 8-10 minute opening "TRAM RIDE" into the Black Mesa facility, and all it really is, is Mr. freeman going into work that day, and that scene alone provides one of the most enigmatic experiences i have ever felt in the prologue of a game.

players enlist the help of traumatized scientists and trigger-happy security guards to get through high-security zones, sneaking and fighting your way through ruined missile silos and Cold War cafeterias, through darkened airducts and subterranean railways. When you finally come in sight of the surface, you realize that the inhuman monsters aren't your only enemies-for the government has sent in ruthless troops and stealthy assassins. Their orders seem to be that when it comes to the Black Mesa, nothing gets out alive... and especially not you. 

That said the journy would be nothing without great enemys with complex ways to kill them like the headcrabs, and nothing would kill them better than the coverted crowbar that "Freeman" Wields. The weapons apart from that are nothing special, exept maybe the laser designated RPG launch

There are no levels in Half-Life, or, more specifically, it lacks the concept of levels and episodes we've come to expect. The game is a continual stream of locations from beginning to end. You can move back and forth at will (with only a few exceptions), as can those who are pursuing you. And though the brief loading time between zones is the one artifact that breaks the flow of the game, the transitions are thankfully brief.

Weapon, ammunition, and health placement follows the same philosophy. You'll hardly ever come across an item that is just bobbing and spinning in place like some gift from the heavens. Valve has done a good job of justifying the typical health and armor meters. Freeman is wearing a hazard suit, used by researchers involved in dangerous experiments. To regain health and armor energy, you must fill up at power stations. These are almost always located in logical places, usually near areas where dangerous work would be performed. There are no power-ups to be found. Weapons and ammo are taken from supply closets or the corpses of fallen security guards and soldiers. Even the more experimental weapons have their proper place - in the weapons research department of the facility. And late in the game, once you've left the research facility, the supply of ammo and first aid kits is believably scarce.

The only problems with Half-Life are the results of it being so ambitious. The fact that all of the humans in the game look like clones takes from the otherwise realistic atmosphere. The diversity of the levels and puzzles will undoubtedly leave you thinking some areas were better than others. But complaints that arise are simply a reaction to the fact that the game is so close to ideal. Half-Life is an exceptional single-player game and a solid multiplayer game.

----------------------------------------

Gordon Freeman... kvantový fyzik pracující ve výzkumném středisku Black Mesa. Vše začíná vaším pozdním příchodem do práce a zdánlivě nepatnými poruchami, i přesto dopustíte test přelomového vynálezu v historii lidstva - teleportu. Test však selže  a dojde ke katastrofě neuvěřitelných rozměrů. Nyní je vše na Gordonovi. Popadne páčidlo, dvě vychlazené desítky a vydá se na cestu skrz celým komplexem , aby vše naparavil než bude příliš pozdě. Cestu mu budou křížit vetřelci, kteří unikli z portálu i armáda, která dostala rozkaz celou katastrofu ututlat.

+ I po letech skvělá hratelnost
+ Nadčasový techno soundtrack
+ Neustálé výzvy vás nutí jít dál
+ Barvitost a atmosféra (prostě věda)
+ Tajemný příběh plný náhlých zvratů

For several years it was the best game I played.

Well, to start off with, I first saw this game in the early 2000 perhaps, and since then I was in love with it. The gameplay combined with the storyline is absolutely stunning. There are tons of maps and the diversity of the environments is mindblowing. To come up up with such an original piece of work (and which is good) is really rare and even more so nowadays. So if you can suffice for a good game and storyline regardless of the graphical representation (which is also quite impressive considering this was out in 1998) this is a must have as it is literally the one that started the legend that the Half Life franchise is today. Oh and one more thing to mention - the physics is pretty darnn good. So if you still want eye candy go and buy Crysis 3 instead (not that I'm bad-mouthing Crysis or anything - I'm also a fan), but if you want to play something that grabs your attention with its wit and ingenuity and dosen't let go  then go ahead and play this game. I can't say enough good things about this game, seriously.

Okay, so you're Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist, some guy who went to MIT. Anyway, generic sci-fi plot, something goes horribly wrong, and then aliens and soldiers everywhere.

So Gordon Freeman picks up a crowbar, announces loudly (without speaking, mind you) "Let's dance,  bitches", and proceeds to take out an alien race and the entire US Army over the course of three days. Overall, the most fun part of the game is shouting "you alien fucks thought you could pick a fight with earth?" and mowing them down with a revolver and a shotgun.

I was also moved by the moral of the story. I interpreted it as "physicists kick ass," but I have also heard people call it "aliens are bitches," "the US Government sure approves a lot of defense funding," and "crowbars should be classified as semiautomatic firearms."

Yes, this game may be older than me - but graphics and sound isn't all that makes an enjoyable game.  As you work your way through Black Mesa Facility after a horrendous scientific disaster you are bewildered by the gameplay which stands up among the best games out today.  It takes around 20 hours to beat without cheats or walkthroughs, and I am sure you will be amazed by the storyline and gameplay which will leave you stuck to your computer screen until you simply fall over (talking from experience).  Half Life started many mods that have also turned into amazing games such as Counter Strike and Team Fortress.  Half-Life is the king of linear video games in my book!

I can't do my normal review system of breaking this game down into simple pros and cons. Let's just say it is a classic FPS, arguably the Forerunner of modern FPS. If you are interested in the progression of gaming throughout the years, this is for you. If you are looking for a sleek modern shooter you may want to pass because Half-Life shows it's age.

Conclusion:
Classic Game

The best franchise I have ever played PERIOD.

Wow... just... wow. What a game we have here. Playing this in the year of 2013 (After having played the wonderful Half-Life 2 some time ago), it's still a joyful experience. The awesome narrative, level design, gunplay and even artificial intelligence still work very well, making it easy to see just how incredibly ahead of its time the game was. Some things that stood out for me in particular were the level design, which changed drastically throughout the game and helped to keep things fresh, the intense (still to this day!) combat, and especially the enemies. Not only were there many different types of enemies, each one interesting and with their very own methods of attack, but for 1998 they were an extremely intelligent bunch of baddies- especially the Special Forces soldiers, who are constantly flanking and lobbing grenades. Not only that, but I found the mini-puzzles to be quite entertaining. All in all, this is one heck of a game, and there's no wonder it's been established as a masterpiece.

A game that never gets old, from the creators of Ricochet, comes this amazing masterpiece that showed a different direction in the First-Person Shooter genre.

I've always considered Half-Life one of the greatest FPS ever created, and for a good reason; This long game has a proper storytelling with no cutscenes, a subtle player agency, fun puzzle-like elements, balanced combat, a variety of weapons and enemies, and lots of well-made locations combined with a superb, badass soundtrack that perfectly immerses you in the Black Mesa incident.

Without a doubt, a must-have.

When I was about 10 or 11, I was searching through a crate of PlayStation games my older brother had given us (my other brother and I). I came across a game labled Half-Life, but as I looked at the game, I realized that it wasnt a PlayStation game at all, but a pc game. I had just started building pc's at the time and had a 90's Dell Dimension, when processors where measured in MHz and rame in MB's. I put the disk in my windows 98' pc and installed it, and when I played the game, well, a strong feeling I couldnt describe came over me, it was the most amazing thing I had ever seen, and I was still in the train at the begining. The game gives sence of emotion and provides moral challanges and puzzles, and when you think you've finished this amazing game, you have only just begun. The game provides more than enough bang for your buck by far. And although the graphics are outdated, it's still the best game I have ever played. I can honestly say it is the game that sparked my love and passion for gaming.

Первая игра серии игр Half-Life, начало знаменитых событий из жизни Гордона Фримена – учёного из научно-исследовательского комплекса Чёрная Меза. Став жертвой обстоятельств, учёный вынужден пробираться через полуразрушенные сектора Чёрной Мезы, таящие в себе множество опасной инопланетной живности из параллельного мира Ксен.
